001
002package gust;
003
004import jsinterop.annotations.JsType;
005
006
007/**
008 * Provides core values, utility methods, etc, which can be used throughout the back- and front-end of a Gust-based
009 * application. Some of these methods or properties will return different values based on where the application is
010 * executed. So, accessing, say, {@link #getEngine()} will return {@code browser} when invoked from JavaScript on the
011 * front-end, and one of {@code jvm} or {@code native} when running on the backend.
012 */
013@JsType
014@SuppressWarnings("WeakerAccess")
015public final class Core {
016  private Core() { /* Disallow instantiation. */ }
017
018  /** Holds the current runtime engine. */
019  static final String currentEngine = System.getProperty("gust.engine", "unknown");
020
021  /** Version of the framework. Injected at build time. */
022  static final String frameworkVersion = System.getProperty("gust.version", "alpha");
023
024  /** Holds the current `dev` flag status. */
025  static final Boolean devMode = Boolean.parseBoolean(System.getProperty("gust.dev", "false"));
026
027  /** Holds the current `debug` flag status. */
028  static final Boolean debugMode = Boolean.parseBoolean(System.getProperty("gust.debug", "false"));
029
030  /**
031   * Retrieve the application version setting, which is applied via the JVM system property <pre>gust.version</pre>.
032   * This value also shows up in frontend libraries as <pre>gust.version</pre>. The default value for this property, if
033   * left unspecified by the runtime, is `alpha`.
034   *
035   * @return Version assigned for the currently-running application.
036   **/
037  public static String getGustVersion() {
038    return frameworkVersion;
039  }
040
041  /**
042   * Retrieve the current engine running this code. By default, this is the string `unknown`. When running in frontend
043   * contexts, this is generally overridden to be `browser`. On the backend, this value is generally either `jvm` or
044   * `native`, depending on how the code is executing.
045   *
046   * @return Current execution engine.
047   */
048  public static String getEngine() {
049    return currentEngine;
050  }
051
052  /**
053   * Returns the current debug-mode flag state, which indicates whether we are running in a debugging-compatible mode or
054   * not. If not, we can generally expect a stripped binary (on the front and back-end), and perhaps expect that symbol
055   * renaming is active.
056   *
057   * @return Whether we are running in debug mode, or production mode (in which case this is `false`).
058   */
059  public static Boolean isDebugMode() {
060    return debugMode;
061  }
062
063  /**
064   * Returns the current dev-mode flag state, which indicates whether we are running locally/in a development context.
065   * This is intentionally separate from {@link #isDebugMode()} to facilitate "production" binary testing in a local
066   * setting. Flip this flag to `true` to enable local RPC calls, logging, and so on, but with a production-optimized
067   * set of artifacts.
068   *
069   * @return Whether we are running in dev mode, or production mode (in which case this is `false`).
070   */
071  public static Boolean isDevMode() {
072    return devMode;
073  }
074
075  /**
076   * "Production mode" is so-called because both {@link #isDebugMode()} and {@link #isDevMode()} return `false`. In this
077   * circumstance, we are running entirely in a mode for production use, in a production context. RPCs should be sent to
078   * endpoints that write and read to/from production databases.
079   *
080   * @return Whether we are running in production mode or not (`true` when `dev` and `debug` are both `false`).
081   */
082  public static Boolean isProductionMode() {
083    return !debugMode && !devMode;
084  }
085}
